answer: Usain Bolt, OJ, CD, (born 21 August 1986) is a Jamaican sprinter. He is the first person to hold both the 100 metres and 200 metres world records since fully automatic time became mandatory. He also holds the world record as a part of the 4 × 100 metres relay. Often described as the fastest man in history, he is the reigning Olympic champion in these three events, as well as the reigning world champion. He is the first person to hold three Olympic gold medals in sprinting events at the same Olympics, and the first to win six Olympic gold medals in sprinting. He is also the only person to win World Championships 100 metres and 200 metres titles in consecutive years (2009–2011).

answer: Rick and Morty is an American adult animated science fiction sitcom created by Justin Roiland and Dan Harmon for Cartoon Network's nighttime Adult Swim programming block. The series follows the misadventures of cynical mad scientist Rick Sanchez and his good-hearted but fretful grandson Morty Smith, who split their time between domestic family life and interdimensional adventures. answer: Social justice is a concept of fair and just relations between the individual and society. This is measured by the explicit and tacit terms for the distribution of wealth, opportunities for personal activity, and social privileges. In Western as well as in older Asian cultures, the concept of social justice has often referred to the process of ensuring that individuals fulfill their societal roles and receive what was their due from society. In the current global grassroots movements for social justice, the emphasis has been on the breaking of barriers that stand in the way of the exercise of human rights by diverse groups of people, an important theme chosen by the United Nations for its annual International Day of Social Justice.

USER:
answer: John Lennon (born John Winston Ono Lennon; 9 October 1940 – 8 December 1980) was an English singer, songwriter, musician, and peace activist who co-founded the Beatles, the most commercially successful band in the history of popular music. With fellow member Paul McCartney, he formed one of the most celebrated songwriting partnerships of the 20th century. Born and raised in Liverpool, Lennon became involved in the skiffle craze as a teenager; his first band, the Quarrymen, evolved into the Beatles in 1960. When the group disbanded in 1970, Lennon pursued a solo career that produced the albums John Lennon/Plastic Ono Band and Imagine, and songs such as "Give Peace a Chance" and "Imagine". After his marriage to Yoko Ono in 1969, he changed his name to John Ono Lennon. Lennon disengaged himself from the music business in 1975 to raise his infant son Sean, but re-emerged with Ono in 1980 with the new album Double Fantasy. He was murdered three weeks after its release.

answer: Bal Gangadhar Tilak (Marathi: बाळ गंगाधर तिळक; 23 July 1856 – 1 August 1920) was an Indian nationalist, social reformer and writer of the Indian Independence Movement. He is remembered as the "Father of the Indian Unrest" for his role in awakening Indian nationalism during the Indian Independence Movement. He was a leader of the Home Rule Movement in colonial India.

answer: Renaissance is a French term for "rebirth", first used in English in the 1830s. The word has several meanings in different historical and cultural contexts. In its broadest sense, Renaissance is a European intellectual movement that was originally a revival of Classical learning and wisdom, and occurred from the 14th to the 17th century. This period is conventionally considered to have begun in Italy in the Late Medieval period, lasting from the 14th to early 17th century, with the Renaissance spreading to the rest of Europe by the 16th century. The Renaissance began as a cultural movement in Italy in the Late Medieval period and later spread to the rest of Europe. This period saw the revival of intellectual thought and wisdom following the Middle Ages, manifested in art, politics, science, religion, and philosophy. The period is considered by many historians to be the "bridge" between the Middle Ages and modern history.

answer: The Twilight Saga (film series) is a series of five romance fantasy films based on Stephenie Meyer's four-book Twilight series. answer: National Council for Peace and Order (Thai: คณะกรรมการสันติภาพแห่งชาติ, RTGS: Kanakham Kam Phanapha Hang Chat) is a military junta that seized power in Thailand on 22 May 2014, ousting the caretaker government of Yingluck Shinawatra. answer: Plato (Greek: Πλάτων Plátōn; 428/427 or 424/423 BC – 348/347 BC) was a Greek philosopher, mathematician, writer of philosophical dialogues, and founder of the Academy in Athens, the first institution of higher learning in the Western world. Along with his mentor, Socrates, and his student, Aristotle, Plato helped to lay the foundations of Western philosophy and science. Alfred North Whitehead once noted: "the safest general characterization of the European philosophical tradition is that it consists of a series of footnotes to Plato." In addition to being a founding figure in Western philosophy, Plato is also one of the most influential sources of religious, philosophical, and political ideas in the West, and his influence on western thought is considered to be second only to that of Jesus Christ.

topic: Daniel Craig, Guildhall School of Music and Drama
answer: Daniel Craig (born 2 March 1968) is an English actor. He trained at the National Youth Theatre and graduated from the Guildhall School of Music and Drama in 1991, before beginning his career on stage. His film debut was in the drama The Power of One (1992), and he gained popularity in the BBC television series Our Friends in the North (1996) and the film Elizabeth (1998), for which he received a BAFTA nomination for Best Actor in a Supporting Role. He also starred in the films Lara Croft: Tomb Raider (2001), Road to Perdition (2002), and Sylvia (2003).

answer: Phalanx is a tactical form of battlefield deployment used by the ancient Greek and Macedonian armies. The term is derived from the Greek φάλαγξ (phalanx), meaning "wedge, wedge-shaped formation of soldiers". The phalanx was a massed formation of infantry, consisting of rows of soldiers equipped with spears, pikes, or sarissas about 5 meters (16 ft) long. The formation was used by the armies of the ancient Greek city-states from the 8th century BC, and remained in use by the Roman Empire.

answer: University of Oxford is a collegiate research university in Oxford, England. There is evidence of teaching as far back as 1096, making it the oldest university in the English-speaking world and the world's second-oldest university in continuous operation. It grew rapidly from 1167 when Henry II banned English students from attending the University of Paris. After disputes between students and Oxford townsfolk in 1209, some academics fled from the city to study in Cambridge; the two sites became known as "Oxford" and "Cambridge" respectively. The University of Oxford is made up of a variety of institutions, including 38 constituent colleges, a dozen academic departments, and a variety of research centres which are organised into four divisions. All the colleges are self-governing entities within the University, each controlling its own membership and with its own internal structure and activities.

answer: Phylogenetic tree is a branching diagram or tree showing the evolutionary history of one or more species—their phylogeny—based on similarities and differences in their physical or genetic characteristics. A phylogenetic tree is constructed so that each branch point (node) represents an ancestral species, and each tip represents the descendants of that species. The tree can be interpreted as a history of a biological species. The phylogenetic tree is a method of displaying the evolutionary relationships among various biological species. Phylogenetic trees are used in many fields of biology, including evolutionary biology, population genetics, and systematics.

answer: Azerbaijan, officially the Republic of Azerbaijan, is a country in the South Caucasus region of Eurasia at the crossroads of Eastern Europe and Western Asia. It is bounded by the Caspian Sea to the east, Russia to the north, Georgia to the northwest, Armenia to the west and Iran to the south. The exclave of Nakhchivan is bounded by Armenia to the north and east, Iran to the south and west, while having a short border with Turkey in the northwest. The Azerbaijan Democratic Republic proclaimed its independence in 1918 and became the first Muslim-majority democratic and secular republic. In 1920, the republic was incorporated into the Soviet Union as the Azerbaijan Soviet Socialist Republic. Azerbaijan proclaimed its independence on 30 August 1991, before the official dissolution of the USSR in December 1991.

answer: Celtic F.C. is a Scottish professional football club based in Glasgow, which plays in the Scottish Premiership, the first tier of the Scottish Professional Football League (SPFL). The club was formed in 1887 with the purpose of alleviating poverty in the immigrant Irish population in the East End of Glasgow. Celtic established itself as a major force in Scottish football following the introduction of the league system in 1890. In 1905, the club won its first league title, which it has won a record 54 times, most recently in 2022.

answer: Foo Fighters is an American rock band formed in Seattle, Washington in 1994. It was founded by Nirvana drummer Dave Grohl after the death of Kurt Cobain and the dissolution of his previous band. The band consists of Grohl (vocals, guitar, and keyboard), Nate Mendel (bass), Pat Smear (rhythm guitar), Taylor Hawkins (drums), and Chris Shiflett (lead guitar). The band released its eponymous debut album in 1995. After the band toured and recorded the album The Colour and the Shape (1997), Grohl became the sole songwriter for the group's subsequent albums. answer: Dodecanese (Greek: Δωδεκάνησα, Dodekánisa, "Twelve Islands") is a group of 12 larger plus 150 smaller Greek islands in the southeastern Aegean Sea, of which 26 have permanent residents. The name is also used to describe the island chain, the island groups, and the geographical region. The islands were first inhabited by the Dorians in the 11th century BC, and were later colonized by the Ionians, the Aeolians, and the Carians. The islands were first unified in the 5th century BC under the name Rhodes, and later became part of the Roman and Byzantine empires. The islands were conquered by the Ottomans in 1522, and remained under Ottoman rule until the 20th century, when they were annexed by Italy. The islands were then occupied by the Germans during World War II, and were freed in 1944. The islands were united under the name Dodecanese in 1947, and were made part of Greece in 1948.

USER:
answer: Led Zeppelin were an English rock band formed in London in 1968. The group consisted of guitarist Jimmy Page, singer Robert Plant, bassist and keyboardist John Paul Jones, and drummer John Bonham. The band's heavy, guitar-driven sound, rooted in blues and psychedelia on their early albums, has earned them recognition as one of the progenitors of heavy metal, though their unique style drew from a wide variety of influences, including folk music. After changing their name from the New Yardbirds, Led Zeppelin signed a deal with Atlantic Records that afforded them considerable artistic freedom. Although the group were initially unpopular with critics, they achieved significant commercial success with albums such as Led Zeppelin (1969), Led Zeppelin II (1969), Led Zeppelin III (1970), Led Zeppelin IV (1971), Houses of the Holy (1973), and Physical Graffiti (1975). Their fourth album, which features the track "Stairway to Heaven", is among the most popular and influential works in rock music, and it helped to secure the group's popularity. Page wrote most of Led Zeppelin's music, particularly early in their career, while Plant generally supplied the lyrics. Jones' keyboard-based compositions later became central to the group's catalogue, which featured increasing experimentation. The latter half of their career saw a series of record-breaking tours that earned the group a reputation for excess and debauchery. Although they remained commercially and critically successful, their output and touring schedule were limited during the late 1970s, and the group disbanded following Bonham's death from alcohol-related asphyxia in 1980. In the decades that followed, the surviving members sporadically collaborated and participated in one-off Led Zeppelin reunions. The most successful of these was the 2007 Ahmet Ertegun Tribute Concert in London, with Jason Bonham taking his late father's place behind the drums.

answer: Audrey Hepburn (born Audrey Kathleen Ruston; 4 May 1929 – 20 January 1993) was a British actress and humanitarian. Recognised as a film and fashion icon, Hepburn was active during Hollywood's Golden Age. She was ranked by the American Film Institute as the 3rd greatest female screen legend in the history of American cinema, and has been placed in the International Best Dressed List Hall of Fame. She is also regarded by some to be the most naturally beautiful woman of all time. Born in Ixelles, a district of Brussels, Hepburn spent her childhood between Belgium, England and the Netherlands. She studied ballet with Sonia Gaskell in Amsterdam, and with Marie Rambert and Doris Mayer in London, before she enrolled in the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art in London in 1948. She made her professional stage debut in that same year.

answer: Elizabeth Taylor (February 27, 1932 – March 23, 2011) was an English-American actress. She began her career as a child actress in the early 1940s, and was one of the most popular stars of classical Hollywood cinema in the 1950s. In 2000, she received the Kennedy Center Honors, and in 2001, she was awarded the American Film Institute's Life Achievement Award.

topic: Transformers: Age of Extinction, Transformers: Age of Extinction
answer: Transformers: Age of Extinction is a 2014 American science fiction action film based on the Transformers toy line. It is the fourth installment in the live-action Transformers film series, and is the sequel to 2011's Transformers: Dark of the Moon. The film was directed by Michael Bay, who co-wrote the screenplay with Ehren Kruger. It stars Mark Wahlberg, Stanley Tucci, Kelsey Grammer, Nicola Peltz, Jack Reynor, Sophia Myles, Li Bingbing, T. J. Miller, and Titus Welliver. The film features the return of several actors from previous films, including John Turturro, Josh Duhamel, Tyrese Gibson, and John Malkovich. The film's score was composed by Steve Jablonsky.

answer: Richard Ramirez (February 29, 1960 – June 7, 2013) was an American serial killer, rapist, and burglar who terrorized Southern California during the mid-1980s. He was dubbed the "Night Stalker" because he broke into homes during the night, often terrorizing his victims while they slept. Ramirez was convicted of thirteen murders, five attempted murders, eleven sexual assaults, and fourteen residential burglaries by a jury in Los Angeles County, California, on August 31, 1989. He was sentenced to death and spent the rest of his life on death row at San Quentin State Prison. He died of complications from B-cell lymphoma on June 7, 2013, at Marin General Hospital in Greenbrae, California.

answer: Charles I of England (19 November 1600 – 30 January 1649) was monarch of the three kingdoms of England, Scotland, and Ireland from 27 March 1625 until his execution in 1649. Charles was born into the House of Stuart as the second son of King James VI of Scotland, but after his father inherited the English throne in 1603, he moved to England, where he spent much of the rest of his life. answer: Tequila is a distilled beverage made from the blue agave plant, primarily in the area surrounding the city of Tequila in the highlands (Los Altos) of the northwestern Mexican state of Jalisco. Tequila is made in five categories: mixto, 100% blue agave, tequila blanco (white), tequila reposado (rested), and tequila anejo (aged). In 2006, there were 106 distilleries registered to produce tequila in Mexico. The agave used in the production of tequila must be grown in Jalisco, Nayarit, Michoacán, Guanajuato, or Tamaulipas. The blue agave is harvested by hand and then cooked in a steam-heated oven to extract the sugars. The core of the cooked agave is then mashed and the juice is fermented, before being distilled and bottled. The agave used in tequila production is a species of the Agave family (Agavaceae).

topic: The Lion King, Walt Disney Animation Studios
answer: The Lion King is a 1994 American animated musical film produced by Walt Disney Feature Animation and released by Walt Disney Pictures. It is the 32nd animated feature in the Walt Disney Animated Classics series. The story takes place in a kingdom of lions in Africa and was influenced by the works of William Shakespeare. The film was produced during a period known as the Disney Renaissance. The Lion King was directed by Roger Allers and Rob Minkoff, produced by Don Hahn, and has a screenplay credited to Irene Mecchi, Jonathan Roberts and Linda Woolverton. Its music was composed by Elton John and Tim Rice, with additional music by Lebo M, Mark Mancina, Jay Rifkin, Julie Taymor, and Hans Zimmer. The original songs were written by John and Rice; one song, "Can You Feel the Love Tonight", won the Academy Award for Best Original Song. The Lion King was released in the United States on June 24, 1994, and grossed over $330 million worldwide, making it the highest-grossing animated film of all time at the time of its release. It was re-released in the United States on January 15, 1997, and in 2002 in the United Kingdom. The Lion King was the first animated film to be nominated for the Academy Award for Best Picture, and the first animated film to win the Golden Globe Award for Best Motion Picture – Musical or Comedy. It is the second-highest-grossing traditionally animated film of all time, behind only Frozen.

answer: Boeing 777 is a family of long-range wide-body twin-engine jet airliners developed and manufactured by Boeing Commercial Airplanes. It is the world's largest twinjet and has a typical seating capacity for 311 to 441 passengers, with a range of 5,235 to 7,370 nautical miles (9,695 to 13,650 km), depending on the model. Boeing marketed the 777 to replace older models such as the 767, 747, and DC-10 in long-range services. The 777 is produced in two fuselage lengths. The original 777-200 first entered service in 1995, followed by the extended-range 777-200ER in 1997. The 777-300, which is 33.3 ft (10.1 m) longer in overall length than the 777-200, first entered service in 1998. The 777-200LR, which is 21.1 ft (6.4 m) longer than the 777-200ER, first entered service in 2006. The 777-300ER is 20.3 ft (6.2 m) longer than the original 777-300. The 777-200LR is the longest-range jet aircraft in commercial service, and the 777-300ER is the largest twinjet and the largest aircraft with a composite fuselage. The 777 is the world's most-purchased twin-engine jet and the second-most-purchased jet aircraft, with over 1,500 aircraft ordered and more than 1,300 delivered as of May 2017.

USER:
answer: Charlie Chaplin (16 April 1889 – 25 December 1977) was an English comic actor, filmmaker, and composer who rose to fame in the silent era. Chaplin became a worldwide icon through his screen persona "the Tramp" and is considered one of the most important figures in the history of the film industry. His career spanned more than 75 years, from childhood in the Victorian era until a year before his death at age 88, and encompassed both adulation and controversy. Chaplin was born in London, England, to Charles Chaplin, Sr., a music hall performer, and Hannah Harriet Pedlingham Hill. As a child, Chaplin was sent to a workhouse twice before being adopted by the Chaplin family when his mother was committed to a mental asylum. After performing in vaudeville with his mother, he was sent to the Fred Karno company, where he began writing and composing music for comic situations. He was placed under contract to Keystone Studios, which assigned him to make 12 two-reel films. He then signed with the Essanay Film Manufacturing Company, where he made 14 two-reel films. After being fired from the Mutual Film Corporation and being sued by Edna Purviance, he traveled to Europe to work on his own films. Afterwards, he returned to the United States and was hired by the First National Film Company to make one-reel films. Chaplin wrote, directed, produced, edited, starred in, and composed the music for his films. His most famous films are City Lights (1931), Modern Times (1936), The Great Dictator (1940), and Monsieur Verdoux (1947). He married four times and had five children with four different women. Chaplin was active in the film industry until the 1950s, when he was accused of communist sympathies, although he denied the charges. He later retired to Vevey, Switzerland, and established a printmaking studio. He died in 1977, and his body was cremated at Corsier-sur-Vevey.

answer: Impeachment is the process by which a legislature brings charges against a public official. Impeachment does not necessarily result in removal from office; conviction following impeachment may result in disqualification from holding office, which historically has been the punishment most often imposed upon convicted officials. In some countries, impeachment is used as a means to remove officeholders who are not convicted of crimes but who are alleged to have committed serious offenses.

answer: Victor Hugo (26 February 1802 – 22 May 1885) was a French poet, novelist, and dramatist of the Romantic movement. Hugo is considered to be one of the greatest and best-known French writers. answer: The Walt Disney Company, commonly known as Disney, is an American diversified multinational mass media and entertainment conglomerate headquartered at the Walt Disney Studios in Burbank, California. The story follows Wade Watts, a teenager who is trying to find a hidden Easter egg in a virtual reality world called the Oasis, which will grant the finder the fortune of the late creator of the Oasis, James Halliday.

answer: Iran, also known as Persia, officially the Islamic Republic of Iran, is a sovereign state in Western Asia. With 82 million inhabitants, Iran is the world's 18th most populous country. Iran is bordered to the northwest by Armenia, the de facto Nagorno-Karabakh Republic and Azerbaijan; to the north by the Caspian Sea; to the northeast by Turkmenistan; to the east by Afghanistan and Pakistan; to the south by the Persian Gulf and the Gulf of Oman; and to the west by Turkey and Iraq. Tehran is the capital and largest city of Iran, while Mashhad is the second-largest city.

answer: Luxembourg (/ˈluksəmbɜːrɡ/ ( listen); Luxembourgish: Lëtzebuerg [ˈlətsəbuəɕ]), officially the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg, is a landlocked country in Western Europe. It is bordered by Belgium to the west and north, Germany to the east and France to the south. Its capital, Luxembourg City, is one of the four official capitals of the European Union and the seat of the European Court of Justice, the highest juridical authority in the EU. Its culture, people and languages are highly intertwined with its neighbours, making it essentially a mixture of French and Germanic cultures. The Luxembourgish language is closely related to both West Germanic German and Romance French.

answer: Apollo 11 was the spaceflight that landed the first two humans on the Moon. Mission commander Neil Armstrong and pilot Buzz Aldrin, both American, landed the lunar module Eagle on July 20, 1969, at 20:17 UTC. Armstrong became the first person to step onto the lunar surface six hours after landing on July 21 at 02:56:15 UTC; Aldrin joined him about 20 minutes later. They spent about two and a quarter hours together outside the spacecraft, and collected 47.5 pounds (21.5 kg) of lunar material to bring back to Earth. Michael Collins piloted the command module Columbia alone in lunar orbit while they were on the Moon's surface. Armstrong and Aldrin spent 21 hours, 36 minutes, and 48 seconds on the lunar surface before rejoining Columbia in lunar orbit.

She received a Golden Globe Award for her performance in Some Like It Hot (1959). Monroe's last completed film was The Misfits (1961), co-starring Clark Gable, with a screenplay written by her then-husband, Arthur Miller. The final years of Monroe's life were marked by illness, personal problems, and a reputation for being unreliable and difficult to work with. USER:
answer: International Space Station (ISS) is a space station, or a habitable artificial satellite, in low Earth orbit. Its first component launched into orbit in 1998, and the ISS is now the largest artificial body in orbit and can often be seen with the naked eye from Earth. The ISS is a modular structure whose components have been launched by Russian Proton and Soyuz rockets, and the American Space Shuttles, and are connected using a series of berthing ports. The ISS program is a joint project among five participating space agencies: NASA, Roscosmos, JAXA, ESA, and CSA. The ownership and use of the space station is governed by international treaties and agreements such as the 1967 Treaty on Principles Governing the Activities of States in the Exploration and Use of Outer Space, including the Moon and Other Celestial Bodies and subsequent treaties.

USER:
answer: Ilkhanate, also spelled Il-khanate, Mongol Empire, or Mongolian Empire, empire founded in 1256 by Hulagu Khan, grandson of Genghis Khan. It was the second great Mongol state, after the Yuan dynasty (1279–1368) of China. Hulagu Khan, who had been appointed by his father, Abagha Khan, as supreme commander of the Mongol forces in Iran, made his capital at Maragha, and his empire covered most of the territory between the Black Sea and the Caspian Sea, including all of Iran and Iraq, as well as parts of the Caucasus, Turkestan, and the Crimea. The Ilkhanate was divided into several provinces, each under a governor.

topic: Little Miss Sunshine, Independent Spirit Awards
answer: Little Miss Sunshine is a 2006 American comedy-drama road film written by Michael Arndt and directed by Jonathan Dayton and Valerie Faris. It stars Greg Kinnear, Toni Collette, Steve Carell, Abigail Breslin, and Paul Dano. The film tells the story of a dysfunctional family who are forced to come together in order to support their youngest son's (Dano) dream of winning the Little Miss Sunshine beauty pageant. The film was released in the United States on July 28, 2006, and received critical acclaim. The film won two Academy Awards: Best Original Screenplay for Arndt and Best Supporting Actor for Alan Arkin.

answer: Wars of the Roses was a series of civil wars fought in England from 1455 to 1485. The conflict was between two rival branches of the royal House of Plantagenet: the House of Lancaster, associated with the red rose, and the House of York, associated with the white rose. The war is also known as the Cousins' War in England, where it is often taught in history classes. The conflict began with the bad relationship between the royal families of Lancaster and York. The war was fought over the throne of England, which was held by Henry VI of Lancaster, who was deposed by his cousin Richard, Duke of York, in 1460.

topic: Arabian Peninsula, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, United Arab Emirates
answer: Arabian Peninsula, Arabic Jazīrat al-ʿArāb, Arabic-speaking region of Southwest Asia that occupies the greater part of the Arabian plateau. It extends from the Red Sea in the west to the Persian Gulf and the Gulf of Oman in the east and from the Isthmus of Suez in the north to Yemen in the south. The peninsula is bounded on the north by the Sinai Peninsula (which is separated from the Arabian Peninsula by the Gulf of Suez), on the east by the Gulf of Aden and the Gulf of Oman, on the south by the Arabian Sea, and on the west by the Red Sea. The total area of the peninsula is about 1,000,000 square miles (2,590,000 square km).

answer: Lymphoma, also known as lymphoid neoplasm, is a type of cancer that develops from lymphocytes, a type of white blood cell. It is the most common cancer in the Western world. answer: Washington Naval Conference, (1921–22), conference held in Washington, D.C., in 1921–22, by which the major naval powers of the world (the United States, Great Britain, Japan, France, Italy, and Belgium) agreed to reduce the size of their navies. The conference was called by U.S. President Warren G. Harding, who wanted to end the naval arms race between the United States and Great Britain.

answer: Measles, also known as rubeola, is a highly contagious viral infection that is transmitted by airborne droplets. The incubation period is usually 10–12 days but can range from 7 to 18 days. answer: Arabian Peninsula, also called Arabian Desert, arid peninsula of Western Asia, extending southward for more than 1,000 miles (1,600 km) from the Red Sea coast of Egypt into the Persian Gulf. The Arabian Peninsula occupies a central position in the ancient and modern history of the Middle East. It is bounded by the Red Sea and the Persian Gulf to the west and south, respectively, and by the Gulf of Aden to the southeast. To the north and northeast, the peninsula is flanked by the Sinai Peninsula of Egypt and the Syrian Desert. The peninsula is divided into three major regions: the coastal plains, the mountains and plateaus, and the deserts. The peninsula is the largest peninsula in the world.

answer: University of Oxford (informally Oxford University or simply Oxford) is a collegiate research university in Oxford, England. There is evidence of teaching as far back as 1096, making it the oldest university in the English-speaking world and the world's second-oldest university in continuous operation after the University of Bologna. It grew rapidly from 1167 when Henry II banned English students from attending the University of Paris. After disputes with other English towns, Oxford received its first royal charter in 1248. After controversies in the next century, Oxford won a competition in 1333 to become the sole English university, and has remained the dominant Oxford University.

answer: Felicity Jones (born 17 October 1983) is an English actress. She made her screen debut in the 2008 film The Diary of Anne Frank and has since appeared in the 2011 films Like Crazy and Hysteria. She also played the role of Jyn Erso in the 2016 film Rogue One, and the title character in the 2017 film The Theory of Everything.

answer: Caspian Sea, largest body of water entirely within Eurasia, lying to the east of the Caucasus Mountains and to the west of the vast steppe of Central Asia. It is bounded on the north by Azerbaijan and Russia, on the east by Kazakhstan and Turkmenistan, on the south by Iran, and on the west by Azerbaijan, Russia, and Turkmenistan. The sea’s name derives from the Caspian Gates (Caspian or Caspian Darya), a narrow strait that connects the Caspian Sea with the Volga River. The Caspian Gates are located at the eastern end of the Volga Delta and are about 35 miles (56 km) wide. The Caspian Sea is the world’s largest inland body of water, with an area of 143,200 square miles (371,000 square km), and the second largest salt lake, after the Dead Sea. It is 266 miles (430 km) long and 184 miles (296 km) wide at its widest point.

answer: Homeland (TV series) is an American political thriller television series developed by Howard Gordon and Alex Gansa based on the Israeli series Prisoners of War (2009), which was created by Gideon Raff. The series stars Claire Danes as Carrie Mathison, a Central Intelligence Agency officer with bipolar disorder, and Damian Lewis as Nicholas Brody, a U.S. Marine Corps Scout Sniper. On April 10, 2013, Showtime renewed Homeland for a fourth season, which premiered on September 29, 2014. On February 5, 2015, Showtime renewed the series for a fifth season. answer: Qatar (Arabic: قطر‎ Qaṭar, officially the State of Qatar), is a sovereign Arab country, located in Western Asia, occupying the small Qatar Peninsula on the northeastern coast of the Arabian Peninsula. Its sole land border is with Saudi Arabia to the south, with the rest of its territory surrounded by the Persian Gulf. A strait in the Persian Gulf separates Qatar from the nearby island country of Bahrain. Following Ottoman rule, Qatar became a British protectorate in the early 20th century until gaining independence in 1971. Qatar has been ruled by the House of Thani since the early 1800s. Sheikh Jassim bin Mohammed Al Thani was the founder of the State of Qatar. Qatar is a hereditary monarchy and its head of state is Emir Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani.

answer: Istanbul is the largest city in Turkey, constituting the country's economic, cultural, and historic heart. It is located on the Bosphorus Strait and extends both on the European Thrace and on the Asian Anatolia sides of the Bosphorus, and is thereby the only metropolis in the world that is situated on two continents. The population of the city has grown from 3 million 800 thousand in 1950 to around 15 million as of 2017.

USER: Write a paragraph about Poseidon (film).
ASSISTANT: Poseidon is a 2006 American action disaster film directed and co-produced by Wolfgang Petersen. It is the third film adaptation of Paul Gallico's 1969 novel The Poseidon Adventure, and a loose remake of the 1972 film of the same name. It stars Kurt Russell, Josh Lucas and Richard Dreyfuss with Emmy Rossum, Jacinda Barrett, Mike Vogel, Mía Maestro, Jimmy Bennett and Andre Braugher in supporting roles. It was produced and distributed by Warner Bros. in association with Virtual Studios. It had a simultaneous release in IMAX format. It was released on May 12, 2006, and received mixed-to-negative reviews but was nominated at the 79th Academy Awards for Best Visual Effects. It grossed $181.7 million worldwide on a budget of $160 million; however, after the costs of promotion and distribution, Warner Bros. lost around $77 million on the film, making it a box-office bomb as a result.

USER: Write a paragraph about Qin dynasty.
ASSISTANT: The Qin dynasty, or Ch'in dynasty, was the first dynasty of Imperial China. Named for its heartland in Qin state, it arose as a fief of the Western Zhou and endured for over five centuries until 221 BC, when it evolved into an empire following its complete conquest of other rival states, which lasted only until 206 BC. It was established in 221 BC when Ying Zheng, who became the king of Qin state in 246 BC, declared himself the first emperor (Shi Huangdi).

He has also won an Emmy Award for his work on the TV series Lonesome Dove (1989). Jones began his career in theater in 1969. He made his film debut in the 1970 Western The Glory Guys, and made his breakthrough in the 1981 war film The Execution of Private Slovik. Jones first gained critical acclaim for his role as Clay Shaw in the 1988 courtroom drama JFK, and gained international fame for his role as Agent K in the Men in Black film series (1997–2019). Jones received an Academy Award nomination for Best Supporting Actor for his role as "W" in the 2005 biographical drama The Man in the Iron Mask.

answer: Cleopatra (1963 film) is a 1963 American epic historical drama film chronicling the struggles of Cleopatra VII, the last active ruler of the Ptolemaic Kingdom of Egypt, to resist the imperial ambitions of both the Roman Empire under Julius Caesar and her younger brother, Ptolemy XIII. answer: Dayton Agreement, also called Dayton Accords, (November 21, 1995), peace accord signed by Bosnian Serb, Croatian, and Bosniak (Bosnian Muslim) leaders that ended the fighting in the Bosnian War and created a new government for Bosnia and Herzegovina. The agreement was negotiated in Dayton, Ohio, U.S., by representatives of the warring factions and U.S. President Bill Clinton, who had sent U.S. diplomats Richard Holbrooke and Warren Zimmermann to the region in September 1995. The agreement provided for the division of Bosnia and Herzegovina into two entities, the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Republika Srpska, and for the establishment of an international peacekeeping force, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO)-led Implementation Force (IFOR).

answer: Rain Man is a 1988 American road comedy-drama film directed by Barry Levinson and written by Barry Morrow and Ronald Bass. It tells the story of an abrasive, selfish yuppie, Charlie Babbitt (played by Tom Cruise), whose father has died and bequeathed his multimillion-dollar estate to his other son, Raymond (Dustin Hoffman), an autistic savant. Charlie, enraged at being cheated out of his inheritance, sets out to get his father's money back by travelling cross-country to bring Raymond home. The film was nominated for nine Academy Awards, winning four, including Best Picture and Best Director for Levinson. The film's screenplay won the Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay. It also won the Golden Globe Award for Best Motion Picture – Drama and Best Actor in a Motion Picture – Drama for Hoffman.

topic: Rick and Morty, Dan Harmon, Justin Roiland
answer: Rick and Morty is an American adult animated science fiction sitcom created by Justin Roiland and Dan Harmon for Cartoon Network's late-night programming block Adult Swim. The series follows the misadventures of cynical mad scientist Rick Sanchez and his good-hearted, but fretful grandson Morty Smith, who split their time between domestic family life and interdimensional adventures. The show's concept originated in an animated parody of Back to the Future by Roiland and Harmon, which they then adapted into a series of short films that were released on Adult Swim's website. Roiland then approached Cartoon Network with the idea, and the channel greenlit the series in early 2012.

topic: Just the Way You Are (Bruno Mars song)
answer: Just the Way You Are (Bruno Mars song) "Just the Way You Are" is a song by American singer-songwriter Bruno Mars from his debut studio album, Doo-Wops & Hooligans (2010). It was released on September 20, 2010, as the album's second single. The song was written by Mars and Philip Lawrence, and produced by The Smeezingtons, a production team consisting of Mars, Lawrence and Ari Levine. "Just the Way You Are" is a love song, in which Mars sings to his lover about how she is perfect just the way she is. The song received generally positive reviews from music critics, who complimented its catchy melody and Mars' vocals. It was nominated for Song of the Year at the 2011 Grammy Awards.

USER:
answer: Rumi (30 September 1207 – 17 December 1273), also known as Jalāl ad-Dīn Muhammad Balkhī, Mevlânâ/Mawlānā, and more popularly simply as Rumi, was a 13th-century Persian Sunni Muslim poet, jurist, Islamic scholar, theologian, and Sufi mystic. Rumi's influence transcends national borders and ethnic divisions: Iranians, Tajiks, Turks, Greeks, Pashtuns, other Central Asian Muslims, and the Muslims of South Asia have greatly appreciated his spiritual legacy for the past seven centuries. His poems have been widely translated into many of the world's languages and transposed into various formats. He is a household name in Persian literature and has been described as the "most popular poet" and the "best selling poet" in the United States.

answer: Prison Break is an American television serial drama created by Paul Scheuring, that was broadcast on Fox for four seasons from 2005 to 2009, and a fifth season which aired in 2017. The series revolves around two brothers: one who has been sentenced to death for a crime he did not commit and his younger brother, who devises an elaborate plan to help him escape prison. The series was produced by Adelstein-Parouse Productions, in association with Original Television and 20th Century Fox Television. The original executive producers were Paul Scheuring, Matt Olmstead, Kevin Hooks, Marty Adelstein, Dawn Parouse, Neal H. Moritz, and Brett Ratner.

USER:
answer: Vedanta (Sanskrit: वेदान्त, IAST: Vedānta) is one of the six schools of Hindu philosophy. It is the most recent school of Hindu philosophy, and the word "Vedanta" literally means "the end of the Vedas". The Vedas are a collection of sacred texts of Hinduism. Vedanta interprets the Vedas and is based on the Upanishads. Vedanta believes that the goal of human life is to gain liberation (moksha) from the cycle of death and rebirth, and achieve unity with the supreme Brahman. It is the goal of Vedanta to bring about the realization of the Brahman within the self. Vedanta has had a profound impact on Indian philosophy, culture and religious practices. It has also influenced other religions, including Buddhism, Christianity, Islam, Jainism and Sikhism.

USER:
answer: Prison Break is an American television serial drama created by Paul Scheuring, that was broadcast on Fox for four seasons from 2005 to 2009. The series revolves around two brothers: one has been sentenced to death for a crime he did not commit, and the other devises an elaborate plan to help him escape prison. The first season focuses on the escape of the younger brother, Lincoln Burrows (Dominic Purcell), from Fox River State Penitentiary, a supermax prison, and how his brother, attorney Michael Scofield (Wentworth Miller), helps him. The second season focuses on Michael's elaborate plan to break Lincoln out of prison, and how his life is affected by the escape. The third season focuses on Michael's efforts to clear his brother's name, while on the run from the law. The fourth season focuses on the aftermath of Michael's escape, and the brothers' reunion, as well as the repercussions of Michael's actions on their families and friends.

topic: The Last of Us Part II
answer: The Last of Us Part II is an action-adventure game developed by Naughty Dog and published by Sony Interactive Entertainment for the PlayStation 4. It was released worldwide on June 19, 2020, having been delayed from its original release date of February 21, 2020. It is the sequel to 2013's The Last of Us, and the fifth game in the Uncharted series. The Last of Us Part II is the first game in the series to be directed by Neil Druckmann, who also served as writer and creative director. The game is set five years after the events of the first game and follows the actions of Ellie and Joel, with Druckmann explaining that the game is "about the cost of revenge and the power of forgiveness".

Before his presidency, Reagan served as the 33rd governor of California from 1967 to 1975, following a career as a Hollywood actor and union leader. Reagan was born in Tampico, Illinois, and raised in Dixon, Illinois. After graduating from Eureka College in 1932, he moved to Los Angeles to become an actor. His film career was marked with roles as a cowboy, including in 51 television episodes of the long-running Cowboy G-Men television series; his nine films with the Monogram Pictures studio are considered "B" movies. In the 1950s, he moved to television, starring in the syndicated series Death Valley Days (1952–1956). He began a career as a motivational speaker. In 1964, he was elected the 33rd governor of California, defeating the incumbent Edmund G. "Pat" Brown. Reagan was re-elected in 1970 and served until 1975, seeing the largest tax hike in California history and advocating the liberalization of abortion law. Reagan was the Republican nominee for president in 1980, campaigning against incumbent Jimmy Carter. His election victory, along with Republican control of both houses of Congress, marked the beginning of the conservative Revolution of 1980. Reagan implemented sweeping new political and economic initiatives. His supply-side economic policies, dubbed "Reaganomics", advocated reducing tax rates to spur economic growth, controlling the money supply to reduce inflation, deregulation of the economy, and reducing government spending. In his first term he survived an assassination attempt, took a hard line against labor unions, and ordered military aid to the Contra rebels in Nicaragua. answer: Benin (; Edo: Bin; Fula: Benin; French: Bénin) is a country in West Africa. It borders Nigeria to the west and north, Chad to the northeast, Cameroon to the east, and Niger to the southwest. Its small coastline on the Bight of Benin is located southwest of Nigeria. The capital is Porto-Novo, but the seat of government is in Cotonou, the country's largest city and economic capital. Benin covers an area of approximately 114,763 square kilometres (44,311 sq mi), and its population in 2019 was estimated to be approximately 11.66 million. Benin is a tropical nation, highly dependent on agriculture, with substantial employment and income arising from subsistence farming.

topic: Back to the Future Part II
answer: Back to the Future Part II is a 1989 American science-fiction adventure comedy film directed by Robert Zemeckis and written by Zemeckis and Bob Gale. It is the sequel to the 1985 film Back to the Future and the second installment in the Back to the Future trilogy. The film stars Michael J. Fox, Christopher Lloyd, Lea Thompson, Thomas F. Wilson, and Elisabeth Shue. The plot picks up exactly where the first film left off, with Marty McFly (Fox) and Doc Brown (Lloyd) having returned to 1985 after saving Marty's parents' romance in 1955. Marty and Doc travel to 2015 to prevent Marty's son from being murdered by Biff Tannen (Wilson). The film is an American-Canadian production, and was shot in California and Ontario.

topic: Liev Schreiber, Golden Globe Awards, Golden Globe Awards
answer: Liev Schreiber (born October 4, 1967) is an American actor, director, and screenwriter. USER:
answer: NASA (National Aeronautics and Space Administration) is the agency of the United States government that is responsible for the nation's civilian space program and for aeronautics and aerospace research. NASA was established in 1958, succeeding the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics (NACA). The new agency was to have a distinctly civilian orientation, encouraging participation by the best scientists and engineers from industry, the Defense Department, and universities, including the previously segregated African-American community. The National Aeronautics and Space Act was passed on July 29, 1958, disestablishing NASA's predecessor, the NACA, and transferring its functions to a new agency in the federal government. The new agency became operational on October 1, 1958.

answer: Ice hockey, often referred to as hockey in Canada and the United States, is a team sport played on ice, in which skaters use wooden or composite sticks to shoot a hard rubber puck into their opponent's net. The sport originated in Canada, most notably in Montreal, where the first indoor game was played on March 3, 1875. answer: Rock music is a broad genre of popular music that originated as "rock and roll" in the United States in the 1950s, and developed into a range of different styles in the 1960s and later, particularly in the United Kingdom and in the United States. It has its roots in 1940s and 1950s rock and roll, a style which drew directly on the African-American genres of blues and rhythm and blues, and was itself directly influenced by gospel music. Rock music also drew strongly on a number of other genres such as electric blues and folk, and incorporated influences from jazz, classical, and other musical styles. The term "rock music" also has been used to describe a form of music made by musicians who were influenced by rock music, but is not strictly a genre.

answer: Hawaii is the 50th and most recent state to have joined the United States, having received statehood on August 21, 1959. Hawaii is the only U.S. state located in Oceania, the only U.S. state located outside North America, and the only one composed entirely of islands. It is the northernmost island group in Polynesia, occupying most of an archipelago in the central Pacific Ocean. The state encompasses nearly the entire volcanic Hawaiian archipelago, which comprises hundreds of islands spread over 1,500 miles (2,400 km). At the southeastern end of the archipelago, the eight main islands are—in order from northwest to southeast: Niʻihau, Kauaʻi, Oʻahu, Molokaʻi, Lānaʻi, Kahoʻolawe, Maui, and Hawaiʻi. The archipelago is physiographically and ethnologically part of the Polynesian subregion of Oceania. The state capital is Honolulu on the island of Oʻahu.

topic: Museum of Science and Industry (Chicago), Chicago
answer: Museum of Science and Industry (Chicago) The Museum of Science and Industry (MSI) is a science museum located in Chicago, Illinois, United States, in Jackson Park. It is housed in the former Palace of Fine Arts from the 1893 World's Columbian Exposition, which was moved to its current location in 1933. The museum is one of the largest in the United States. It covers 14 acres (57,000 m2) and holds more than 35,000 artifacts.

answer: The New Adventures of Old Christine is an American television sitcom that ran on CBS from March 13, 2006, to May 12, 2010, for a total of 98 episodes. It was created by Kari Lizer and stars Julia Louis-Dreyfus, Clark Gregg, Hamish Linklater, and Wanda Sykes. The series was produced by CBS Productions and Chuck Lorre Productions. It was one of the first shows to be produced by the newly formed CBS Studios. The series was filmed on Stage 19 at CBS Studio Center in Studio City, Los Angeles. The series was originally developed as a spin-off of Seinfeld.

answer: John Glenn (July 18, 1921 – December 8, 2016) was a United States Marine Corps aviator, engineer, astronaut, and politician. He was the first American to orbit the Earth, circling it three times in 1962, and later became a U.S. senator from Ohio. Born in Cambridge, Ohio, Glenn was a graduate of New Concord High School and Muskingum College, where he was a star athlete in football and baseball. He was a distinguished fighter pilot in World War II and Korea, and flew 149 missions. He was one of the few pilots to fly both the F4U Corsair and the F8F Bearcat. He was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross six times. Glenn was selected as one of the original NASA Mercury Seven astronauts in 1959. He made his first spaceflight, Friendship 7, on February 20, 1962, becoming the first American to orbit the Earth, circling it three times in 4 hours, 55 minutes. He received the NASA Distinguished Service Medal, the NASA Distinguished Service Medal, the NASA Exceptional Service Medal, the NASA Space Flight Medal, the Lindbergh Eagle Scout Award, and numerous other awards.

answer: Elizabeth II (Elizabeth Alexandra Mary; born 21 April 1926) is Queen of the United Kingdom and the other Commonwealth realms. Upon her accession on 6 February 1952, Elizabeth became Head of the Commonwealth and queen regnant of seven independent Commonwealth countries: the United Kingdom, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, South Africa, Pakistan and Ceylon. She has reigned through major constitutional changes, such as devolution in the United Kingdom, Canadian patriation and Australian republican referendums. Her many historic visits and meetings include a state visit to the Republic of Ireland and visits to or from five popes. She has seen major constitutional changes, such as devolution in the United Kingdom and Canadian patriation, and has occasionally intervened in British politics. Elizabeth has occasionally faced republican sentiments and press criticism of the royal family, in particular after the breakdown of her children's marriages, her annus horribilis in 1992, and the death in 1997 of her former daughter-in-law Diana, Princess of Wales. The Queen is an active member of the Commonwealth, and is head of the Commonwealth Games Federation. She is also head of state of 32 countries and territories with a combined population of 200 million, known as the Commonwealth realms, of which the United Kingdom is the most populous. In her personal capacity, she is known as the Queen.

topic: Taraji P. Henson, Think Like a Man
answer: Taraji P. Henson (born September 11, 1970) is an American actress. She studied acting at Howard University and began her Hollywood career in guest-roles on several television shows before making her breakthrough in Baby Boy (2001). Henson received Academy Award, Screen Actors Guild Award, Golden Globe Award, and BAFTA Award nominations for her lead performance in The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008). She received a second Academy Award nomination for her supporting role in Hidden Figures (2016). In 2018, she starred in the film Proud Mary, and was nominated for a Golden Globe Award for Best Actress in a Motion Picture – Drama for her role in What Men Want (2019).

answer: England, officially the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, is a sovereign country in western Europe. The United Kingdom includes the island of Great Britain, the north-eastern part of the island of Ireland, and many smaller islands. Northern Ireland is the only part of the United Kingdom that shares a land border with another state: the Republic of Ireland. Apart from this land border, the United Kingdom is surrounded by the Atlantic Ocean, with the North Sea in the east, the English Channel in the south and the Celtic Sea in the south-west. The Irish Sea lies between Great Britain and Ireland. With an area of 242,495 square kilometres (93,620 sq mi), the United Kingdom is the 80th-largest sovereign state in the world and the 11th-largest in Europe. It is also the 21st-most populous country, with an estimated 66.0 million inhabitants.

USER:
answer: Animal Farm is an allegorical novella by George Orwell published in England on 17 August 1945. According to Orwell, the book reflects events leading up to and during the Stalin era before World War II. Orwell, a democratic socialist, was a critic of Stalinism and what he saw as corrupt and oppressive governments in general. The Soviet Union was the first country to publish the book, in 1946. Animal Farm is Orwell's best-known work, and, along with his other political novels, 1984 and Nineteen Eighty-Four, it is widely considered a classic of modern literature.

answer: Russia, or the Russian Federation, is a transcontinental country in Eastern Europe and Northern Asia. At 17,125,200 square kilometres (6,612,100 sq mi), it is by far the largest country in the world, covering more than one-eighth of the Earth's inhabited land area, and the ninth most populous, with over 144 million people as of 2018. Extending across the entirety of Northern Asia and much of Eastern Europe, Russia spans eleven time zones and incorporates a wide range of environments and landforms.

answer: Performance (film) is a 1970 British crime film directed by Donald Cammell and Nicolas Roeg. It stars James Fox, Mick Jagger, Anita Pallenberg, and Michèle Breton.
